content.title: Introduction to Environmental Science
content.description: Understanding our planet and the challenges it faces

content.title: What is Environmental Science?
content.description: The scientific study of our environment

content.title: Defining Environmental Science
content.content: Environmental science is an interdisciplinary field that integrates physical, biological, and information sciences to study the environment and find solutions to environmental problems. It encompasses ecology, geology, meteorology, biology, chemistry, and physics. The field examines how humans interact with their environment and the impacts of human activities on natural systems.
content.paraphrase: Environmental science combines multiple scientific disciplines to study nature and human impacts. Key fields: ecology, geology, biology, chemistry, physics. Focus: understanding human-environment interactions.

questions.question: Which is NOT a component of environmental science?

content.title: The Scientific Method
content.content: Environmental scientists use the scientific method to investigate problems. This involves: 1) Making observations, 2) Forming a hypothesis, 3) Designing and conducting experiments, 4) Analyzing data, 5) Drawing conclusions. This systematic approach ensures findings are reliable and reproducible.
content.paraphrase: Scientific method steps: Observe → Hypothesize → Experiment → Analyze → Conclude. This ensures reliable, reproducible results in environmental research.

content.title: What is an Ecosystem?
content.content: An ecosystem is a community of living organisms interacting with their physical environment. It includes biotic factors (plants, animals, microorganisms) and abiotic factors (water, air, soil, sunlight). Energy flows through ecosystems via food chains and food webs, while nutrients cycle between organisms and the environment.
content.paraphrase: Ecosystem = Living things + Physical environment. Biotic (living): plants, animals. Abiotic (non-living): water, air, soil, sun. Energy flows through food chains; nutrients cycle continuously.

content.title: Biodiversity and Its Importance
content.content: Biodiversity refers to the variety of life on Earth at all levels: genetic, species, and ecosystem diversity. High biodiversity provides ecosystem services like clean air, water purification, pollination, and climate regulation. The current rate of species extinction is 1,000 times higher than natural levels, making biodiversity conservation critical.
content.paraphrase: Biodiversity = Variety of life (genes, species, ecosystems). Benefits: clean air, water purification, pollination, climate control. URGENT: Extinction rate is 1000x higher than natural!

content.title: Climate and Climate Change
content.description: Understanding Earth's climate system and human impacts

content.title: Weather vs Climate
content.content: Weather refers to short-term atmospheric conditions like temperature, precipitation, and wind at a specific time and place. Climate is the average weather patterns over a long period (typically 30+ years) in a region. A simple way to remember: 'Climate is what you expect, weather is what you get.'
content.paraphrase: Weather = Short-term conditions (today's temperature, rain). Climate = Long-term average patterns (30+ years). Remember: 'Climate is what you expect, weather is what you get.'

content.title: The Greenhouse Effect
content.content: The greenhouse effect is a natural process that warms Earth's surface. When the sun's energy reaches Earth, some is reflected back to space while the rest is absorbed. Greenhouse gases (CO2, methane, water vapor) trap some of this heat, keeping Earth warm enough to support life. Without it, Earth would be about -18°C (0°F).
content.paraphrase: Greenhouse effect: Sun warms Earth → Some heat trapped by gases (CO2, methane, water vapor) → Earth stays warm. Natural process! Without it, Earth = -18°C (freezing cold).

content.title: Causes of Climate Change
content.content: Human activities have increased greenhouse gas concentrations since the Industrial Revolution. Main causes: 1) Burning fossil fuels (coal, oil, gas) for energy, 2) Deforestation, which reduces CO2 absorption, 3) Agriculture, especially livestock producing methane, 4) Industrial processes. CO2 levels have risen from 280 ppm to over 420 ppm.
content.paraphrase: Human causes of climate change: 1) Fossil fuels (coal, oil, gas), 2) Deforestation (fewer trees to absorb CO2), 3) Agriculture (livestock methane), 4) Industry. CO2: 280 ppm → 420+ ppm since 1800s.

content.title: Effects of Climate Change
content.content: Climate change impacts are already visible: rising global temperatures (1.1°C above pre-industrial levels), melting ice caps, rising sea levels, more extreme weather events, shifting ecosystems, and ocean acidification. These changes threaten food security, water availability, human health, and biodiversity.
content.paraphrase: Climate change effects we see: +1.1°C global warming, melting ice, rising seas, extreme weather, ecosystem shifts, ocean acidification. Risks: food, water, health, biodiversity all threatened.
